I believe the American people want fewer taxes, smarter spending in Washington, and a balanced budget.
Their budget grows government spending by nearly $5 trillion over the next ten years. That's something I cannot and will not support.
While many want to focus on reducing taxes for all Americans, the House Progressive Caucus is pushing a budget to raise taxes by $7 trillion
The House of Representatives is voting in an open and transparent process on a series of budget proposals from Republicans and Democrats.
This week, the American people will have a clear vision of what direction each party wants to take our country.

We’re taking the first step towards a tax code based on the radical idea you deserve your take-home pay more than Washington bureaucrats do.
From middle class to the poorest of the poor, the majority of hardworking families have been left behind in our economy over the last decade

As monthly bills continue to rise, our plan makes sure you get to keep more of your hard-earned money. 

READ:https://fairandsimple.gop/?utm_source=RepKevinYoder …

Today, we're announcing the framework of a plan to cut taxes for working families across America.

As we debate what to do about DACA recipients, why wouldn't we also address a huge injustice that affects as many - or more - immigrants?
As they raise their families as Americans & work toward permanent residence, they're facing a huge obstacle in our immigration laws.
Hundreds of thousands - maybe even millions - of hardworking people from India are here in the US working hard, contributing to our economy.
Immigrants who are here in the US like Sunayana don't deserve to get stuck in a decades-long backlog for their green card. We need HR 392.
Appreciate the mention on @PreetBharara's podcast. We'll continue to help Sunayana & advocate for HR 392. More here:http://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/article172037307.html …

The AHCA devotes $8 billion over five years to further stabilize the premiums of the small subset of people who would be affected. (2/2)
FACT: On top of the $130 billion investment in risk mitigation programs in the AHCA (1/2)
Even if you have a gap in coverage, insurers can only charge you a higher premium for 12 mos, then you pay same premiums as everyone else.
FACT: As long as you have continuous coverage, you CANNOT be charged more based on health status in ANY state.
They can waive out of this regulatory framework ONLY for individuals who have gone more than two months without purchasing insurance. (2/2)
If states can show they have new innovative solutions to protect individuals with preexisting conditions in a better way (1/2)
FACT: Under the AHCA, rules that prevent denying coverage or charging more expensive rates based on health status remain the law of the land
Myth vs. Fact: How does the AHCA affect people with preexisting conditions http://yoder.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/american-health-care-act-myth-vs-fact …

We specifically prohibit denying coverage based on preexisting conditions. Here’s the bill text from Section 136:pic.twitter.com/qUMcyUgKgO
Despite misinformation being spread, no one with preexisting conditions can be denied access to coverage under the American Health Care Act.

How about @RepDaveJoyce, another one of the 300 Email Privacy Act cosponsors. What were you up to at 29? #ECPA29
.@RepSeanDuffy what were you up to at 29? Another cosponsor of the Email Privacy Act. #ECPA29
.@TulsiPress is another Email Privacy Act cosponsor. What were you up to at 29? #ECPA29
.@RepChrisStewart is another Email Privacy Act cosponsor. What were you up to at 29? #ECPA29
.@RepRodBlum, our office neighbor in the Cannon Building, is another Email Privacy Act cosponsor. What were you up to at 29? #ECPA29
.@RepSchrader is another Email Privacy Act cosponsor. What were you up to at 29? #ECPA29
.@RepKinzinger is another Email Privacy Act cosponsor. What were you up to at 29? #ECPA29
.@HurdOnTheHill is one of the 300 cosponsors of the Email Privacy Act. What were you up to at 29? #ECPA29
.@RepJaredPolis what were you up to when you were 29? #ECPA29
On ECPA's 29th birthday, we're trying to raise awareness by using the hashtag #ECPA29 and asking what you were doing at age 29. (7/7)
Email Privacy Act has 300 cosponsors in the House - a veto-proof super majority. But hasn't seen a hearing in committee yet. #ECPA29 (6/7)
Our digital communications, which are far more common in our 2015 world, deserve same protections as our paper communications. #ECPA29 (5/7)
.@RepJaredPolis and I have introduced the Email Privacy Act (HR 699) to bring our 4th Amendment rights into the 21st Century. #ECPA29 (4/7)
ECPA allows federal agencies to access any of your digital communications older than six months WITHOUT a warrant. #ECPA29 (3/7)
That's right, President Reagan signed ECPA into law 29 years ago today - and it's still governing our digital privacy rights. #ECPA29 (2/7)
In addition to it being #BackToTheFuture Day, today happens to be the Electronic Communications Privacy Act's 29th Birthday. #ECPA29 (1/7)
